group_1.textRight: I see...

group_1.textLeft: (I can't believe the university professor@actually called me.)

group_1.textRight: Yes, I'd say this is a very strong argument.
You didn't spare any expense in analyzing your@sources!
I'm honestly astonished that you wrote this@while still in high school.
That said...
There's two noticeable weak points in this@argument.
The first are these haniwa fragments, reportedly@from the Edo period.
I'm impressed by how you found this record of@them, as it's fairly obscure.
But as far as the fragments' origin goes...
The academic community has essentially reached a@consensus already.
You know how there's several small kofuns in the@hill's vicinity, right?
Based on where the fragments were discovered...
There's a high likelihood that they came from those surrounding kofuns.
Secondly...
If we suppose that this hill is a kofun, the@main issue is its shape.
Yep.
Since the hill's round, it'd be categorized as@an "enpun"-- that is, a circular kofun.
If it's the real deal, it'd be quite a large@enpun indeed...
But every other large-scale kofun discovered in@this region has been a "zenpou-kouen-fun"...
That is, a keyhole-shaped kofun.
Perhaps it was built in a different era than the@ones around it... but that's also hard to imagine.

group_1.textLeft: So... if it were a kofun, it'd have to be an@outlier among outliers?

group_1.textRight: I'm afraid so.
Without logical explanations for these two@points...
It'll be difficult to overturn the established@theory.
It was very convincing, though.
After all, we've found plenty of small-scale@enpuns in the area...
...So it'd be easy to believe, if only the hill@were smaller.
Still, though, it was a very well-written paper!
I hope you keep up your studies.
I can tell that you're going to be an amazing@researcher some day.

group_1.textCenter: A primary historical source...!@This is priceless!
